sec.title: Appendix
sec.p:
The expected value of the IRRP distribution (1) is
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$E\left({y}_i\right)=\sum \limits_{y_i=0}^{\infty }{y}_iP\left({y}_i\right)=\sum \limits_{y_i=0}^{\infty }{y}_i{\left(1+\frac{y_i}{\theta_i+{\delta}_i}\right)}^{y_i-1}{\left({\theta}_i{e}^{-\left\{\frac{\theta_i}{\theta_i+{\delta}_i}\right\}}\right)}^{y_i}/{y}_i!{e}^{\theta_i}=\left\{1+\frac{\theta_i}{\delta_i}\right\}{\theta}_i\to {\theta}_i, when{\delta}_i\to \infty .$$\end{document}

Of interest in scrutinizing the data evidence, whether the MLE of the impact parameter statistically small involves dealing with the correlated sample mean and variance. Only in the case of normally distributed data, the sample mean and variance are independent [ 4]. Let
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${\rho}_{\overline{y},{s}_y^2}$$\end{document}
ρ
y ¯
,
s y 2
be the correlation between the sample mean and sample variance. Utilizing the formulas in Blumenfeld [ 3], we obtain that
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$E\left(\frac{\overline{y}}{s_y^2}\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right)=\frac{E\left(\overline{y}\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right)}{E\left({s}_y^2\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right)}\left\{1+\frac{Var\left({s}_y^2\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right)}{E\left({s}_y^2\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right)}\right\}-\frac{\rho_{\overline{y},{s}_y^2}\sqrt{Var\left(\overline{y}\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right) Var\left({s}_y^2\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right)}}{{\left\{E\left({s}_y^2\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right)\right\}}^2}$$\end{document}

The constant adjusted odds of having no count are the ratio
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$1+{\mathrm{odds}}_{\delta \ne \infty }=\Pr \left(y=0\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right)/\Pr \left(y\ge 1\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right)\Big]=\frac{e^{-\theta {e}^{-\left\{\frac{\theta }{\theta +\delta}\right\}}}}{\Pr \left({\chi}_{2 df}^2<2\theta {e}^{-\left\{\frac{\theta }{\theta +\delta}\right\}}\right)}$$\end{document}

. A measure of vulnerability change under restrictions in a category is defined as
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${\mathrm{Vulnerability}}_i=\frac{E\left[y\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right]}{Var\left[y\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right]+E\left[y\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right]}-0.5=\frac{\left\{{\delta}^2-{\left(\delta +\theta \right)}^2\right\}}{2\left\{{\delta}^2+{\left(\delta +\theta \right)}^2\right\}}$$\end{document}

. The tail value at risk ( TVaR
i ) is commonly used in the business world and it can be fitting here to describe the risk at an outbreak of pandemic like COVID-19. It is
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$TVaR=E\left[y\left|y\ge 1,\theta, \delta \right.\right]=1+\frac{\sum \limits_{y=1}^{\infty}\left(y-1\right)\Pr \left[y\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right]}{\Pr \left[y\ge 1\left|\theta, \delta \right.\right]}=\frac{e^{-\theta \left[{e}^{-\left\{\frac{\theta }{\theta +\delta}\right\}}-1\right]}}{\Pr \left({\chi}_{2 df}^2<2\theta {e}^{-\left\{\frac{\theta }{\theta +\delta}\right\}}\right)}$$\end{document}
